edu.uchsc.ccp.dmap
Class Pattern

java.lang.Object
  edu.uchsc.ccp.dmap.Pattern

public class Pattern
extends java.lang.Object

A pattern is what DMAP is looking to find in the input text.

Here it is represented as a tree of subpatterns that organize base elements. The base elements are what can actually be recognized. The patterns place various sorts of ordering constraints on the base elements within the pattern.

Patterns can be normalized or not. A normalized pattern has been massaged until it's first element is a single base element that can be recognized by the parser. Normalizing a pattern may require generating an arbitrary number of alternate patterns with different initial base elements.

Author:
R. James Firby, Will Fitzgerald

getContent

public DMAPItem getContent()
Returns:
Returns the content.

setAsMainClause

public void setAsMainClause(boolean value)

isNormalized

public boolean isNormalized()
Predicate to tell if this pattern is normalized or not.

A normalized pattern has been massaged to be expecting a single recognizable parser item.

Returns:
Whether this pattern has been normalized

getKey

public DMAPItem getKey()
Get the base element that this normalized pattern starts with.

Returns:
The normalized base element

normalize

public java.util.Vector<Pattern> normalize()
Process a pattern to find the first base element that it is waiting for. There may, in fact, be many possible base elements so this method may return a collection of new patterns, each normalized to a different element. This method may copy as much or as little of the pattern as required. Normalizing a pattern should always result in a sequence.

Returns:
The normalized versions of this pattern.

advance

public java.util.Vector<Pattern> advance()
Advancing a pattern moves it forward to the next base element that the parser should be looking for. Advancing a pattern generates only normalized results. Thus, advancing a pattern may also generate an arbitrary number of new patterns.

Returns:
The new, advanced, normalized versions of this pattern

toPatternString

public java.lang.String toPatternString()
Return the pattern as a string that could be read back in.

Returns:
A readable pattern string

toNormalizedString

public java.lang.String toNormalizedString()
Return that pattern as a normalized 'prediction'. This will start with the first item the pattern is expecting, a dot, and then the pattern.

Returns:
A 'prediction' view of a normalized pattern

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Return the pattern as a string
